_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Our company strives to maintain a safe and healthy work place.  Out farmer owners, managers, and employees have made every effort to plan the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  This company is an agricultural retail business which specializes in grain storage for area producers, as well as providing the necessary inputs for grain production.  
Our plant consists of three anhydrous storage tanks, one 18,000 gallons and two 12,000 gallons, and 61 nurse trailers holding approximately 250,100 pounds, and when everything is filled to the 85% capacity, will hold approximately 535,100 pounds.  The worst case scenario may potentially release 79,000 pounds (over a ten minute periods) and has a distance to endpoint of 2.50 miles.  This release has the potential to affect 800 area residents.  
The alternative release scenario would have a release of 11,908 pounds over a two minute period.  This release would have a distance to endpoint of .83 miles and would still affect 800 people within the community.  
This company maintains and operates their NH3 plant in strict accordance with all federal, state, and local authorities.  The Kansas Department of Agriculture inspects our plant on a regular basis and we comply with their requests for improvement.  Our employees are trained in safety procedures, proper plant operation, plant maintenance, and the employees are competency tested over the training material.  Each employee uses goggles and gloves during ammonia operations as well as always providing plenty of safety water during nurse tank loading operations.  
With the above mentioned training in mind, it makes it very simple to report to you that absolutely no injury accidents or property damage has occurred at this facility for the past five years.  
Our Emergency Response Plan is designed to minimize the risks to employees, the surrounding public, and the area first responders.  This company provides plant tours for our local fire department and our
plant has been shared with the county LEPC.  They are aware of the dangerous nature of NH3 and they have agreed to assist us in the event of an emergency.
